pulfalight.title: Do not include physloc notes in "located in" field
Implement collection-level badges indicating the access permissions for the resource

comments.body:
@sdellis @tpendragon The only values currently in our EADs are "open", "closed", and "review". This was changed by ADAPT fairly recently. 

In ASpace, both "review" and "closed" will be set to "restrictions=>true" in ASpace ("open" will correspondingly be "restrictions=>false"), with the text of the restriction stored in "notes". On the top_container record, the default value for the type of restriction will most likely be a generic "Restricted"--we're still in the process of working that out with Lyrasis--and the text of the note I believe will be in "active_restrictions".

While we have more information here I think we still need an explicit specification of exactly what to pull or map from aspace into the text of these badges. Are we pulling the contents of the `active_restrictions` field? Or are we mapping from the `restrictions` boolean value? I'm not sure whether "type of restriction" is another field in the mix here.

LAE086 can be used for testing; it has `<physloc type="code">rcppf</physloc>`

But this seems blocked by #288 for now

pulfalight.title: Display folder number ranges at the parent level in addition to the extent note that says however many folders or containers are represented by the parent level

comments.body: I think this issue is resolved now? @apferrar?

Though I did spot another issue looking into this. The physloc text notes associated with container records, which note where in the stacks an item is located, should not display on the site. This is for staff use only. For example, see: https://pulfalight-staging.princeton.edu/catalog/aspace_C1491_c5621. "D-zone" should not display on the site. Should another issue be created for this?
@faithc I made https://github.com/pulibrary/pulfalight/issues/451
Thanks!

pulfalight.title: Draft a Usability Testing Script

comments.body: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1V2yPYpX-YjzZ6fUPrTyhBWlzYAIUNZE3P9EenpqPxNY/edit#heading=h.h1kbujq3z7xy is what we started writing up

pulfalight.title: Integrate accessibility testing into the continuous integration workflow

comments.body:
Okay we found the right axe gem that we can use within our feature tests (updated links in description). This seems like the easiest way forward.

The consequence of going this direction is that any failure will block merge because it will be an actual test failure.

The lighthouse integration would be harder to implement, but if we did move that direction at some point it would give us comments on PRs rather than test failures. I.e. it wouldn't block merge but it would give us useful feedback.

with axe-core-rspec you have to tell it to run against wcag2a, wcag2aa, wcag21a, and wcag21aa to get all the rules. Here's the documentation: https://github.com/dequelabs/axe-core/blob/5e951536a6b4f21ef4d4a849b575b5a3c1ec6b85/doc/rule-descriptions.md

comments.body: @apferrar can speak more to this in terms of instructions for users; however, one piece of content that's ready to go is this statement: https://library.princeton.edu/special-collections/statement-language-archival-description.

@hackmastera I've drafted some text for each section and [it's in the drive](https://docs.google.com/document/d/13i_44Py4LESJyKrcwA9YvjSSeIIE3K9LykD-BTJ0sRw/edit). I'm not sure how much we'll actually need, but I was basing it off of what existed on the old [Special Collections Research Account blog](https://blogs.princeton.edu/research-account/).

pulfalight.title: Notes at parent level(s) should filter down to child components

comments.body: Yes. The data in the spreadsheet explains how collection-level notes should be managed. Thanks.
Actually, @regineheberlein, does the encoding that we included in the spreadsheet still apply now that we're talking about ASpace records?
@faithc No, that needs to be revised--it'll be wrong especially for the descgrp cases.
Drats. How might you propose doing that? I'm not familiar with the ASpace exports at all. Should this be brought to Will and Armando's attention?

@tpendragon Do you need the EAD nesting structures of those notes to be revised for ASpace EAD flavor in the spreadsheet? Do you even use the EAD exporter anymore? ASpace keeps notes associated with resource/archival object records in "notes"=>[].
@regineheberlein It'd be helpful if they could be revised. We could probably stumble our way through it if y'all don't have time, but I can't promise much accuracy. We still use the aspace EADs.
Will do! @tpendragon still the SVN ones? Or can you point me to where test EAD files now live?
@tpendragon Done, based on the SVN ones for now. @faithc NB that some of the instructions in the Notes column are also now obsolete; I've added this where I noticed
Thanks, @regineheberlein!
